result.execSummary:
The defendant William John Morgan was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • OWI (5th or 6th), a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(1)(a).
  • Possess w/ Intent-Amphetamine(<=3g), a class F felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(1m)(e)1.

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

superMiscConds.notes: If probation is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due. All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.

Absolute Sobriety, AODA assessment and treatment follow through, cognitive behavioral interventions treatment, Dirver's Safety programing, victim impact panels, and other treatment/programing deemed appropriate by supervising agent.

supervisions.notes:
Pursuant to the provisions of Section 343.301, of the Wisconsin Statutes, the Court orders that for a period of 36 months, on each motor vehicle for which the defendant's name appears on the vehicle's certificate of title or registration be equipped with an ignition interlock device.

Also, pursuant to the provisions of Section 343.301, of the Wisconsin Statutes, the Court further orders that for a period of 36 months, beginning on the date the Department of Transportation issues any license to the defendant granted under Ch. 343, of the Wisconsin Statutes, the defendant's operating privileges for the operation of Class D vehicles be restricted to operating vehicles that are equipped with an ignition interlock device.

superMiscConds.notes: If probation is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due. All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.

DNA surcharge if not already provided
Voting rights
Firearm restriction

11:04 AM - cases called 14CF106 and 18CF110.  Defendant, William John Morgan appeared via telephone conference.  Court was informed by District Attorney that the District Attorney is not taking a position on this motion and does not appear.  Court also spoke with Clerk of Court who is against motion.  Court questions Defendant regarding treatment.  Responses by Defendant.  Statements by the Court.  Statements by Defendant regarding motion.  Court questions Defendant.  Responses by Defendant.  Statements by the Court.  Response by Defendant.  Court will deny motion for civil judgment on both cases.  Statements by Defendant.  Statements by the Court.

10:14 AM - case called.  Defendant, William John Morgan appeared in custody via video conference from Prairie du Chien.  State does not appear.  Statements by the Court - Court spoke to the District Attorney off the record and the State does not take a position on Defendant's petition for sentencing adjustment.  Statements by Defendant.  Statements by the Court - two petitions - Count 1 and Count 2.  Court has reviewed petitions and Defendant's letter.  Statements by the Court.  Court grants Defendant's petitions for sentence adjustment on Counts 1 and 2.  Statements by Defendant regarding 75%.  Response by the Court.  Defendant directed to speak with Dept. of Corrections.

Defendant, William John Morgan appeared via video conference.  Galen Bayne-Allison appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Case called.  Statements by Atty Bayne-Allison regarding Defendant's letter to the Clerk of Courts asking to amended JOC to give Defendant additional sentence credit.  State opposes his request - Defendant was given credit in this matter and in 15CF218.  Statements by Defendant regarding jail credit.  Court granted 101 days in this matter and 188 days to be given if revoked in 15CF218 case.  Statements by Atty Bayne-Allison.  Court addresses Defendant regarding charges and cases.  Defendant claims revocation of all cases per document he received.  State takes the position that a case needs to be specifically listed not just a box checked.  Court needs a revocation and warrant on 15CF218 for it to apply.  Defendant's understanding is that he is being revoked on everything.  Defendant advised that comes from the Dept. of Corrections.  State shows revocation on extended supervision.  Court has reviewed the transcript from hearing and Court did grant 101 days in this matter and 188 days in 15CF218 if revoked.  Court will send Defendant's agent a letter and ask for agent's opinion.  Statements by Defendant - has a jury trial set for December and has an attorney for that matter.

Hearing on October 19, 2018 at 10:30 am.
Defendant's copy provided to Dodge Correctional
from the Defendant to the Court
